name: Bifidobacterium breve
summary: A probiotic species studied for gut health, immune modulation, and potential benefits in mood, cognition, and metabolic conditions.
description: Bifidobacterium breve is a gram-positive, anaerobic probiotic bacterium commonly found in the human gut microbiome, particularly in infants. It contributes to digestive health by fermenting carbohydrates into short-chain fatty acids (SCFAs), modulating the immune system, and competing against pathogenic bacteria. It has been studied for gastrointestinal disorders, allergic diseases, metabolic syndrome, and emerging applications in psychiatry (gut–brain axis).

metadata.natural_source: Human gut microbiota (especially infant gut); fermented foods
metadata.fda_status: Generally Recognized as Safe (GRAS) for some strains

primary_indications: Allergic rhinitis and atopic dermatitis (in children)
off_label_uses: Metabolic syndrome (lipid and glucose metabolism support)
Adjunctive use in depression and anxiety (gut-brain axis, limited evidence)
contraindications: Severe immunocompromise (risk of bacteremia, though rare)

sections.text: Bifidobacterium breve contributes to gut health by fermenting dietary fibers into short-chain fatty acids (e.g., acetate, butyrate) that support intestinal barrier integrity and immune regulation. It modulates gut microbiota composition, reduces inflammation, and may influence the gut-brain axis through microbial metabolites and vagal signaling.

adult.note: Often combined with other probiotic strains in multi-strain formulations.

sections.pediatric: Commonly studied at 1–3 billion CFU daily in infants/children for allergic and GI disorders
sections.geriatric: Similar to adult dosing; some strains studied for cognitive health

sections.text: GI benefits may be noticeable within days to weeks; immune modulation and psychiatric/metabolic effects may require longer-term supplementation (≥8–12 weeks).

serious: Rare bacteremia in severely immunocompromised individuals

other: Strain-specific efficacy: clinical benefits depend on the exact strain used.
Not a substitute for standard medical therapy.

items: Signs of systemic infection in high-risk populations

sections.pregnancy: Generally considered safe; often included in perinatal probiotic blends
sections.lactation: Safe; may support infant microbiome development
sections.pediatrics: Extensively studied in infants and children; commonly used
sections.geriatrics: Safe; studied for cognition and gut health

sections.text: Not required; benefits may diminish after discontinuation as strains do not permanently colonize.

items: B. breve is one of the dominant species in the infant gut and supports early immune development.
Certain strains (e.g., B. breve M-16V, B-3, Yakult strains) have been studied for specific clinical applications.
Efficacy is highly strain-dependent; generalization across all B. breve supplements is not appropriate.

seo.description: Comprehensive guide to Bifidobacterium breve, a probiotic studied for digestive health, immunity, allergies, metabolism, and emerging psychiatric applications.
